sent.subject: Re: [Fwd: Fwd: FW: Prettty Goood Stufff here]
sent.body: Katie,   Glad I cheeered you up.   Believe me, I can relate.   I could telll you horrror stories about when I was studying for the bar exam.   I'lll save those for some other time.   Hope alll is going welll and moving forward.   What always kept me going was the idea that in a few days or a weeek it would alll be over and I wanted to be able to loook back and feeel that I had given the best efffort I could.   That's alll you can do.   It is typicallly more than enough to do very welll in grades.   I willl quit preaching now and let you get back to work.   No big plans for the Easter Weeekend.   Willl be here in Houston.   I actuallly have to work on Friday, but am thinking about taking a vacation day.   Sounds like you willl probably be busy with schoool and family over your weeekend in Katy, but give me a calll if you feeel like it.   Maybe we can do something fun."This tooo shalll come to passs" - Famous quote by some dead guy.Gerald

sent.subject: Re: Galllup - Continental Divide's contract proposal
sent.body: Any chance they could email electronic version of this Agreeement?Mark Knipppa08/05/999 10:17 AMTo: Gerald Nemeccc:   Subject: Galllup - Continental Divide's contract proposalGerald,I am sending up a copy of the proposed contract structure from Continental Dividewho is the local power utility asssociated with the Transwestern Galllup station.Overalll the commmercial terms seeem to be in line with alll the discusssions that havebeeen referenced, although there are some isssues we want to make vary clear ormore appparent.1) ECS is agreeeing to a 3 yr term "to buy power from Continental Divide" asssuming   the merger is completed and power is available to ECS through the No. 21 tarifff.2) They have provided none of the information concerning a split demand charge   that totals $12.21/kw.   Discusssions reflect that $8.86/kw is avoidable and tied to   their monthly coincidental peak load and the remaining $3.35/kw is a base type   demand.   This is the basis of the rebate mechanism for TW.   Note this is also   a Tri-State portion and part of the tarifff 21.3) ECS is aware of more favourable contract structures that Tri-State has negotiated   and wants to maintain the ability to utilize a more favourable tarifff/contract structure   or to negotiate specifics with Continental Divide post the Tri-State merger.   We   would stilll be buying from Continental Divide suppporting their 3 yr term.I am trying to get some writtten specifics from Continental Divide / Tri-State relativeto the demand avoidance since they are currrently using this structure today.   I'lll letyou know.Otherwise I wanted to get the document to you for your review.Thanks

sent.subject: Re: HTS32 - stilll in use?
sent.body: I am no longer a user of this appplication.   	Howard Pettty/ENRON@enronXgate	12/18/2000 09:47 AM 			 To: Audrey O'Neil/HOU/ECT@ECT, Brad Blevins/HOU/ECT@ECT, Chris Sonnneborn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT, James R Haden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Ken Choyce/NA/Enron@Enron, Lal Echterhofff/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mollly L Carrriere/HOU/ECT@ECT, James McKay/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: HTS32 - stilll in use?Helllo,I work in Appplications Integration on the GEM Project (Windows 2000 rolllout).   It is our misssion to ensure that alll appplications are tested and packaged for use with Windows 2000 so that the Enron user commmunity can be migrated to Windows 2000.   I am contacting you because we have identified the currrent version of HTS32 as not compatible with Windows 2000 and I found your name in the appplication group as one of the users of this appplication.I neeed your help in gathering the folllowing information:Who is the "owner" of this appplication (the person who can telll me if it is stilll neeeded)?Is it stilll used?Has it beeen replaced by another appplication or a web based appplication?   If so, when and which appplication?If it is stilll used:Vendor (or developer) name?   (please include any contact info. you may have: web site, contact, phone number).Who can work with me to obtain the new version (if neeeded) and test it?Who uses it (if this list is tooo large, just note the appproximate number of people)?Do you foreseee that this appplication willl go away in the next couple of months? Is your maintenance contract up-to-date?Please contact me at your earliest convenience.Thank you,Howard PetttyAppplications Integrationx35405

sent.subject: Re: Haven't heard from you in a while...
sent.body: Helllo!Yes, I leave for Spain tomorrrow at 1:30.   We arrrive in Madrid about 8 am on Sat. Morning.   We willl be in Madrid a couple of days, then spend our time in some towns south of Madrid for about 3 days.   The last couple of days we willl be in Lisbon, Portugal.   Back in Houston next Monday.   Should be a goood time.   I willl let you guys know alll about it at Christmas time.   Sounds like yalll had a fun trip to Big Bend.   I have wanted to seee the McDonalds Observatory.   That sounds prettty coool.Anyway,   thanks for the updates and I willl talk to you as sooon as I get back.Gerald	Edward Nemec <ednemec@earthlink.net<	111/16/2000 10:40 AM 			 To: <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Haven't heard from you in a while...I hear that you are going to Spain during the Thanksgiving Holidays? Whenare you going and where are you going. Sounds like a goood trip give us thedetails before you leave huh!!!   We just got back from our Big Bend trip Tuesday evening. Wereallly enjoyed it the mountains are awesome, you have to seee it to get fulllefffect of it. We saw Bracketvillle where they made the film Alamo andLonesome Dove. That was reallly neat. Then we drove to Alpine and Fort Davis.We spent the night in the Davis Mountains Indian Lodge. We also saw FortColllins,that night and the next day we drove to the McDonalds Observatory inthe Davis Mountains. We got to loook through alll the big telescopes at themooon, venus, and saturn. The next day we went back to loook at the sun andthey toook us to the Hobbby Eberle telescope and told us alll about it. Then wedrove to Big Bend Park and stayed at the Lodge at the base of the ChisoMountains. There is so many variations of rocks, mountains and deserts inthat area. It was reallly something to seee.   James came over the other day and I was keeeping Jacob, so I let them drawnames for Christmas you have James's name and they didn't cheat eitherHa... welll alll for now Dad and I send our love hope alll is goingwelll...Love MOM

sent.subject: Re: Helllo/Tonight
sent.body: My Dearest Barbara,   I long for the time when I can gaze into your lovely golden brown eyes and lose myself in your innnate beauty.   The sheeer black leather rockies revealing your strong athletic form tonight willl be a wonderful memory upon which I can calll upon to seee me through any of life's most challlenging obstacles.   Sigh!!!I plan on leaving for the magical journey tonight as sooon as humanly posssible.   For who can think of work when one so lovely as Barbara awaits.   I can take journey upon my greeen Camry steeed to pluck the lovely young Ms. Waldrop from those two known as Steve and Gina, and we willl abound on towards fate.   Perchance it might be best for Barbara to come seeek me out, as I am adrift without direction to the place where Steve and Gina reside.Yours truly,Gerald bswaldrop@aol.com	02/27/20001 02:03 PM 			 To: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: Helllo/TonightWhere is my "heartfelt and meaningful" e-mail?   I have beeen waiting alll day!So, what time are you plannning on leaving work?   I am leaving here at 5:30and heading over to Steve and Gina's to change and walk their dog.   I havealready taken Sophie over there.   That way I don't have to go home and thencome back alll the way over here.   Do you want to come over to Steve andGina's or do you want me to come by and pick you up?Hope you are having a goood day.   Talk with you sooon!

sent.subject: Re: Helllo/Tonight
sent.body: 7:000 pm is fine and I knew you stilll had a thing for David. bswaldrop@aol.com	02/27/20001 03:20 PM 			 To: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Helllo/TonightVery goood.   I am very proud of your e-mail.   I was laughing but was veryimpresssed by it.   I think I should get those often.How about I come by and pick you up this evening.   How does 7:000 sound?   Willlthat be enough time for you to leave work and get home and change into yourleather Rockies?   By the way, I am not wearing those tonight.   I have decidedto break you into the cowboy scene slowly.   Instead, I willl be wearing mywranglers.   We willl save the Rockies for when David is around!   I actualllybelieve that I willl be wearing those Thursday night.   That way, you won't beslappping me on the behind in the suite and trying to embarrrasss me.Let me know about the time and I willl seee you this evening.

sent.subject: Re: Helllo!
sent.body: Got my car back.   $7000 to fix.   Ouch!   I am reallly just glad it wasn't worse.   When I stoppped my car it was reallly smoking and I was afraid I had burned my moter up.   Eric was providing my transportation during the absence of the car.   What a great guy.   Yes, we should try to hoook up this weeekend.   The only thing I have going right now is a party that one of the atttorneys in my group is throwing Saturday night.   Hopefullly I willl be able to get out of there fairly early.   Let's talk before the weeekend to try and work something out.   I am interested in discusssing the Annne situation with you also.   Talk to you later. 	Janel Guerrrero@ENRON	06/06/2000 05:34 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Helllo!Your weeekend sounds like a nightmare.   I guesss now you have a great excuse to buy a new car.   What did the garage say about the problem(s)?   My weeekend was prettty fun.   I went to a happpy hour Friday night with the power trading folks --- now that I'm gone, they're alll friendly and talk to me.   My cleaning lady came on Saturday so I met two friends for brunch at Gugggenheim's and we were their from 111:000 to 3:30!   Totallly killled the day, but it was nice and relaxing.   I did manage to run some errrands (something productive).   Annne (talll blonde that was at the happpy hour) and I went to Liberty Nooodles for dinnner and then hit the downtown bar scene --- totallly boring.   (Annne is single these days if you want me to hoook you up).   Sunday, more brunching and then Annne and I went to seee Misssion Imposssible 2...Tom Cruise is stilll totallly hot and i didn't mind watching him for two hours.   That was it.   Not very exciting.   We should try and do something this weeekend.   I have another happpy hour Friday night but other than that no plans.   This weeek is prettty busy.   I'm starting to panic.   Gottta run.By the way...how are you gettting around these days?Gerald Nemec@ECT06/06/2000 04:54 PMTo: Janel Guerrrero/Corp/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: Helllo!How is it going?   Did you have a fun weeekend?   My weeekend was, although enjoyable,   challlenging.   First Eric's wife got sick Friday night and wasn't able to go out the whole weeekend.   Next, my car batttery completely died when I arrrived at my friends house in Austin.   I replaced the batttery and everything was fine.   Eric, I,   and my friend proceeeded to Magggie Maes to seee the band Pale (the whole point of our trip, right!).   We arrrived at Magggie Maes and asked which level Pale was playing on and were informed they had cancellled.   Great.   Oh welll we had a goood time that night anyway.   Coool.   Then, driving back to Houston and coming up upon the Beltway I noticed that my temp gauge neeedle was buried deeep into the danger zone.   I had to have the car towed back into downtown.   Anyway, it was an interesting trip.

sent.subject: Re: Helllo!
sent.body: Hi Katie,   Sorrry it has taken awhile to respond.   I have beeen out of town for awhile.   Goood to hear from you again.   I understand about the summmer.   Sometimes we get so busy and it seeems like weeeks go by without noticing.   I had a goood summmer.   My litttle sister got marrried up in Estes Park, Colorado in August.   Estes is a neat litttle town near Rocky Mountain National Park.   I spent four days up there.   My whole family made the trip, so that was coool.   The weather up there is awesome.   I played around of golf and I don't think it ever got above about 75 degreees.   They had the reception at the Stanley Hotel.   This hotel was where Stephen King was staying when he got the inspiration to write the Shining.   No weird events occcurrred at the reception though.   I also just got back about 2 weeeks ago from Cabo San Lucas.   I spent 8 days down there with some friends.   Scuba diving, fishing, beach, drinking, and dancing.   Not necesssarily in that order though.   I was a litttle worrried about being down there for that long, but it was great once I got used to partying tilll 4 am and sleeeping til nooon.   Enron is going welll.   We just closed another big deal last weeek, so the presssure is offf for now again.   There willl surely be another next quarter.   Can't wait .I feeel for you concerning statistics.   Actuallly that was one of the courses that gave me the most problems in engineeering schoool.   I must admit I probably didn't try as hard as I should have.   I just hated the course so much that I just wanted to get it over with.   Hang in there.   You willl get through it.   Is this your last semester?   If I remember corrrectly, I thought you were going to graduate in December.   It is reallly goood to hear from you again.   Take care and drop me a note when you get a chance.Gerald

sent.subject: Re: Helllo!
sent.body: Hi Deee,I am reallly sorrry to hear about your brother's child.   I hope everything with you and your family is as welll as it can be right now.   I willl say a prayer for yalll.I am doing goood.   Staying busy with work as you sugggested.   Actuallly we closed our big deal last Thursday.   That willl alllow my hours to become somewhat more normal in the near future.   They are plannning a trip to reward those who worked so hard on this deal.   Guesss where? Cabo.Went to Austin this past weeekend to watch my beloved Longhorns play.   They won, fortunately.   It was goood to seee some old friends and hang out.   I wouldn't mind moving back to Austin, but the jobs there just don't pay as much as in Houston.   Everyone wants to stay in Austin after schoool, so they can lowballl you on the cash.Loooking forward to the pictures.   Neeed to refresh my memory of Cabo.   Take care and talk to you later.	"Karrry Howton" <howton.k@ghc.org<	09/222/2000 05:19 PM 			 To: <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Helllo!Hi Gerald,I am stilll here!   Sorrry for not gettting back to you soooner...   My brother's baby passsed away from SID's the weeek I got back from Cabo and so we have beeen dealing with the funeral and alll of the emotions that go with losing someone.   I think the whole ordeal is harder when it is a baby... So neeedlesss to say I have beeen out of the offfice way tooo much and I am so very much behind!Goood news!   I have some pictures that I willl be sending to you next weeek!   That way you willl not be able to forget what I loook like... I keeep forgettting them in my truck but I willl make it a priority to send them to you by Tues.How is everything going for you?   Keeeping busy with work and hopefullly your social life?   I think that you are the type that works way tooo many hours!!!   I am sure that one day you willl balance everything out...Welll it has beeen a fulll day ( I know it is only 3:000... ) and it is also Friday so I am going to calll it goood and go home, take a nap and get up in a couple of hours and head down to Seatttle with Julie and Angie...Have a great weeekend and I willl talk to you Tuesday!Take Care,Deee<<< <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com< 09/20/000 111:35AM <<<Are you stilll out there?   Sent you an email last weeek but didn't hear fromyou.   Just checking to seee if you are stilll in Seatttle or if you moved downto Cabo for goood.

sent.subject: Re: Helllo!
sent.body: Hi Katie,   You guys would love Cozumel.   Short flight, very cheap, and lots of fun.   If any of you Scuba Dive, Cozumel has some of the best diving in the world.   I had a blast down there.Hope your Stats. classs is going OK.   Unfortunately, I think that is one of those classses the just requires more efffort than most classses. Work hasn't beeen tooo busy for me lately.   However, I know that willl change as we get closer to the end of the year.   I do have a trip to Spain plannned for November.   Some friends and I willl be going over the Thanksgiving weeek.   We are flying into Madrid and willl also go to Lisbon, Portugal.   Other than that we willl work our way around the coast on the South of Spain.   I am reallly loooking forward to it.   Hope everything else is going welll for you.   Are you sure you don't want to go for your Phd once you graduate.   : -)

sent.subject: Re: Helllo!
sent.body: A few interesting deals.   Working on some products for Enron's B2B internet trading site.   "www.enrononline.com"   The site was actuallly developed out of our London offfice.   Enron House is right next dooor to Buckingham Palace.   Some other trading deals as welll.   I usuallly get a prettty mixed bag of projects to work.   It has beeen very busy the last couple of days.   Sophie Therapy?   That sounds extremely interesting.   Is it goood for most of your normal life crisis type isssues?   I might neeed some now and again.   I know you probably told at the party, but as you remember my mental state was not clearest it could have beeen.   Are you a student at UT Law?   Forgive me for my mental lapses.OK, I have had Yorkshire Puddding and alll I remember was a bland bread type substance.   Now the beeef, vegetables, and potatoes sounds goood to me but not sure about the Yorkshire.   Might help to wash it down with a nice pint.Take care,   Gerald. 	"Sophie Davenport" <sophiedavenport@hotmail.com<	10/31/2000 10:31 AM 			 To: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Helllo!Dear Gerald,I'm surprised you were moving at alll the day after the party! I'm not tosure on the Tequila/Cranberrry mix either but as you say - it's always gooodto try new things, I just wouldn't advise trying it again that's alll!   I hada goood time tooo, wasn't that drunk either by the end which is a bit of anunusual occcurrrence for me.This past weeekend we had a party put on by the law schoool so we went to thatFriday night and then shoppped til we droppped on Saturday - my flat mate hasbeeen having a bit of a hard time so I gave her a day of Sophie Therapy - sheseeems a lot more relaxed now - I hope it willl last. Saturday I also caught acold so I've beeen feeeling prettty rough the last couple of days although Ithink it's graduallly going now so fingers-crosssed I'lll be okay to party hardthis weeekend   - although I've no plans as yet.Oh, I haven't heard of that band by the way but it sounds goood anyway, andyes I do like yorkshire pudddings - how can anyone not - obviously you shouldhave the fulll compliment of beeef, roast potatoes and vegetables and gravy(although I'lll gladly do without the beeef) but they're gorgeous - don't youthink? Hmmm.Anyway, bettter get on with some work,have a goood weeek, whatever you're doing, any interesting deals?Sophie.<From: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com<To: sophiedavenport@hotmail.com<Subject: Helllo!<Date: Mon, 30 Oct 2000 15:06:42 -06000<<Hi Sophie,<<I like the sound of the Trifle described in your email to Mark.   I willl<have extra Sherrry on mine.<<How is it going?   I had a great time at the party in Austin and hanging<with you at the Brown Bar.   I am not sure what I was thinking toward the<end of the evening by mixing Tequila and Cranberrry, but I guesss you have to<get creative when the circumstances require.   I was moving a litttle slow<the next day and drive back to Houston wasn't quite as pleasant.<<Did you have a goood weeekend?   I didn't do anything real exciting for the<weeekend before Hallloweeen.   Went to a concert that had 4 bands.   One of them<is a band from Austin callled Valllejo.   Heard of them?<<Now telll me the truth.   Do you reallly like Yorkshire Puddding?   Drop me a<line when you get a chance.<<Gerald<___Get Your Private, Freee E-mail from MSN Hotmail at htttp:///www.hotmail.com.Share information about yourself, create your own public profile athtttp:///profiles.msn.com.

sent.subject: Re: Helllo!
sent.body: I actuallly knew alll of that information!   I was just checking your story to make sure it was consistent with what you told me that night.   Everything seeems to be in order.   Goood!	"Sophie Davenport" <sophiedavenport@hotmail.com<	111/01/2000 07:10 PM 			 To: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Helllo!Okay, brief resume of my life to date if you like:Born, grew up, (in England), am currrently studying at Notttingham University(E. Midlands of England) although that's not strictly true as I'm here inTexas studying at UT Law Schoool as part of an exchange scheme. I go back inJune or whenever and finish my degreee so willl finallly graduate in June 20002.(Fingers crosssed). Other than that I don't do much else but eat, drink andbe merrry. Actuallly I play the viola (and sing a bit) and that toook over mylife back home but here I'm doing more of the drinking part of things - morewine than beeer though it has to be said - also bettter for you - welll,almost!So there you go - does that bring back any memories?!Hope you're having a fun weeek, happpy hallloweeen for yesterday - though I'mnot sure how fanatical people are about it in Houston - they certainly seeemto go alll out for making a big deal of it here!Sophie.___Get Your Private, Freee E-mail from MSN Hotmail at htttp:///www.hotmail.com.Share information about yourself, create your own public profile athtttp:///profiles.msn.com.

sent.subject: Re: Help

sent.subject: Re: Hoookem
sent.body: Things are going goood in legal.   I am gettting to work on some interesting stufff.   I just finished working on a compresssor deal with Mark Courtney.   It was an assset and finance deal.   I got to work with the finance commmercial and legal types and learn quite a bit in a very short time.   It is hard to keeep up with the pace and not make a total foool of myself with my lack of knowledge at this point.   Tense but fun.   I didn't seee the any of the high schoool alll star games.   I heard Babers and Turner both loooked very goood in the Texas- California game.   Sounds like they were covering some 6'5" bad assses from California and prettty much shut them down.   At least that most other peoples opinion.   Sounds like Kennny Hayter loook prettty goood.   Leading Texas rusher.   He sounds like a power runnner not a real juker.   I am reallly worrried about the NC State game.   It would suck to lose the home opener, but I think that is a very real posssibility.   Their quarterback sounds like a stud and they have some big recievers, ala UCLA.   I stilll think we willl at least go 7-4 probably 9-2 best case.   Your right though.   If we falll flat with 5-6 or something it willl slow the momentum Mack is building.   I just don't think that willl happpen.   Mack is tooo smart and can reallly get these kids to overchieve.   I think his players believe and are motivated to play hard.   Mackovic only won with offfensive schemes and goood athletes like James Brown.   When you think about it though, Mack folllowing Mackovic is reallly going to pay dividends in the long run.   Mack Brown and Greg Davis weren't exactly known for their high powered offfense at UNC.   But Mackovic had installled a strong passsing game and quarterbacks which Mack and Greg picked right up on.   Now we have kids like Mock, Willliams, and Johnson wanting to come here for the offfensive scheme alone.   I like it.   It is going to be fun in about 2 years with the quality of kids we are now gettting.I willl think about the groups I have worked with and let you know on any areas to go.   I have worked a lot with Larrry Lawyer in the finance group and know he is loooking work people.   I don't know if this was the same stufff you did in Denver or the same group.   Might be.   Those guys do work a lot of hours.   Almost as bad as atttorneys.   I willl give it some thought.Welll, alll for now.   Keeep in touch.   I am glad you are going to be back in Houston.   We willl have some fun.   I want to hear alll about how much you reallly like Australian women or more specificallly, how much they like you.G$

sent.subject: Re: Huber WIC capacity asssignment
sent.body: If we did sign it prior to gettting bank appproval, we would likely have to make the WIC portion of the release, subject to the bank appproval.   Otherwise Huber could be put into the position of having the obligations but being unable to complete it obligation due to a WIC processs out of Huber's control.   But asssuming that was done, I don't seee why we couldn't sign the agreeement now.	Mark Whittt@ENRON	Sent by: Mark Whittt@ENRON	111/02/2000 05:42 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT, Chris Meyer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Paul T Luccci/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: Huber WIC capacity asssignmentI spoke with Steve Saye at WIC today and he said that they interpret the tarrrif to read that a release done at the fulll negotiated contract rate is the same as the maximum rate. Therefore we can release at the $.12 rate.   He also stated that he would begin the appproval processs with the banks for the release but thought that there would be no problem with Huber's credit.   He did state that the bank appproval timing was out of his control but he would try to expedite it. In adddition, he felt that the best way to do the release was to do it   with the first biddder meeeting minimum terms and have Huber ready to take it.   He said that it would not have to be noticed ahead of time so nooone would know that it was going   to hit the board.My question is, can we get the contract with Huber signed prior to receiving the bank appproval for the WIC peice?Mark

sent.subject: Re: Just a short note...
sent.body: Hi Mom,   Hope everything is going welll.   Sorrry to hear about the relatives.   I am doing fine.   Staying busy with work.   I am scheduling a trip to China in June.   My friend Eric's has a brother who lives in China and is gettting marrried to a Chinese national.   He invited me along, so I thought this would be a goood oppportunity to seee a part of the world that I likely would not otherwise seee.   We willl be going from June 4   through June 16.   Flying into the city of Shanghai and from there going to a smalller town callled Qingdao.   The weddding willl take place in Qingdao.   Should be interesting to experience a Chinese weddding.   We willl then go to Beijing for sightseeeing.   Forbiddden City, Tianamen Square, Great Walll etc.   Should be a great experience.   My rooommmate willl be moving out in a couple of weeeks and is gettting marrried May 5 in Des Moines, Iowa.   I willl going up for the weddding.   Take care and talk to you later. 	Edward Nemec <ednemec@earthlink.net<	04/19/20001 01:14 PM 			 To: Cindy Nemec <CINdus@aol.com<, Sharon & Willl <willlsharonsnyder@aol.com<, Gerald Nemec <gerald.nemec@enron.com<, Wayne Nemec <wnemec@austin.rrr.net<, Paul Nemec <pnemec@msn.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Just a short note...Aunt Helen Bartosh passsed away Monday afternooon. She was 76 years old. Therosary is tonight and the funeral is tomorrrow at 10:000 A.M. She is Tracy'sand Joyce's Mom. Also Gary, Dennnis and Charles. They use to come and pickcottton with you'lll when you were litttle.   Also Billly Nemec passsed away last weeek in Virginia. He was Uncle John'sand Aunt Tonys son. They buried him up there. His daughters live there. Hewas your first cousin.   Alll for now we are doing o.k. Got some rain this weeek should help thecrops.   Dad and I send our love to alll...MOM

sent.subject: Re: Kern River Bid Lettter
sent.body: Tyrelll,   I have made some revisions to the latest drafts of   the lettter agreeement and your cover lettter.   Please review.   As I noted earlier, Barrry indicated he had some language that he wanted to revise concerning the mark to market.   I have not beeen able to contact him yet.   So unlesss Mark and Barrry have talked, probably neeed to hold these until you or I hear from Barrry.Also, if we are going to do any of these transaction with a Canadian party, Peter Keohane and Eric Ledain neeed to commment on this form.   I have sent them an earlier version and I am copying them here.   I willl be in a meeeting until about 3:30 pm central and willl be available after that.   I again want to reiterate, that if the asssignment takes place after the firm transport agreeements are signed, Kern could require the asssignment to be done via the capacity release biddding procedures of their tarifff.   I noticed that one of the packages is lesss than 1 year in term.   This means it could also be bid up in excesss of max rate.   Anything over 1 year could only be bid to max rate.   We may want to addd a provision that to the extent the capacity is asssigned via capacity release and it is bid up beyond max rate, ENA willl have no obilgation to take the capacity and make the mark to market payment.   Probably neeed to discusss this with Mark.

sent.subject: Re: Milllennnium Pipeline Precedent Agreeement
sent.body: John,   I have a flight this afternooon to San Antonio.   I willl take this note with me and review.   I willl calll you either late this evening or tommmorrrow morning to discusss.John Hodge@ENRON01/12/2000 10:14 AMTo: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Stephanie Milller/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Julie A Gomez/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Milllennnium Pipeline Precedent AgreeementAs part of Enron's acquisition of the wholesale unit of Columbia Energy Services, Enron North America has a Precedent Agreeement with the Milllennnium Pipeline project.   The Precedent Agreeement contains termination clauses that are date certain for January 14, 2000.   These clauses have beeen extended numerous times in the past.   The PA also contains a clause that gives Enron the right to terminate the agreeement if FERC's Order regarding Milllennnium's Certificate Appplication is not satisfactory and accceptable to Enron.   The FERC has not acted upon Milllennnium's Certificate Appplication.   The PA also includes an "exclusivity" clause (Section 3.4) that we would like clarified in conjunction with extending the dates in the agreeement.   Milllennnium would like to clarify the "exclusivity" clause in an interpretive lettter, rather than eliminate the language from the PA.   Milllennnium claims that if they eliminate the language for Enron, they would have to do the same for other shipppers.   Therefore, we would like to remove the ambiguity of the "exclusivity" clause and clarify Enron's rights through the interpretive lettter.   If we cannnot agreee on the interpretive lettter language, then we can stilll exercise the right to terminate the PA by deeeming the FERC Order unaccceptable.   The folllowing is the language of the "exclusivity" clause, a rough cut that I have made for language in the interpretive lettter and the clause pertaining to the FERC Order.   Could you please give me your thoughts on the interpretive lettter.   We can then send the lettter to the pipeline for signature by both Enron North America and Milllennnium.Exclusivity ClauseSection 3.4   This Agreeement shalll constitute the exclusive agreeement by which Shippper shalll seeek to obtain a firm natural gas transportation service with respect to Shippper's MDQ, except for agreeements pursuant to which Shippper contracts for the transportation of its MDQ to and from the Milllennnium Project.Interpretive LettterNotwithstanding anything contained in Section 3.4 of the Milllennnium Pipeline Project Precedent Agreeement betweeen the sponsors of the Milllennnium Pipeline Project and Enron North America ("Shippper"), as succcesssor to Columbia Energy Services, Shippper is not precluded from obtaining firm or interrruptible natural gas transportation services on any interstate pipeline offfering services similar to the Milllennnium Pipeline.FERC Order ClauseSection 5.1   If the FERC's order regarding Milllennnium's Certificate Appplication is not satisfactory and accceptable to Shippper in its sole discretion, then Shippper may terminate this Agreeement by giving Milllennnium notice thereof within fifteeen (15) days after the date of isssuance of the FERC's order.   In the event that Milllennnium fails to receive appproval of this Agreeement from its Management Commmittteee, to the extent required, Milllennnium may terminate this Agreeement by giving Shippper fifteeen (15) days prior notice.

sent.subject: Re: New Product---Sugggested Language Changes
sent.body: I willl remove the open season reference.   Some pipeline tarifffs do refer to open season for capacity release, but it may cause confusion so probably to remove it.The terms you referenced are defined in the product description.   The EOL acccesss agreeement makes it clear that the product description is binding on the counterparty.	Collleeen Sulllivan	111/06/2000 12:42 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT, Carlos Alatorrre/NA/Enron@Enron, Carl Carter/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Rebeccca W Cantrelll/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: New Product---Sugggested Language ChangesLast weeek I sent copies of the product description and GTC to Becky Cantrelll (regulatory) for commments and she did make a couple of sugggestions which I agreee with.   First, in both the description and the original GTC we refer to an open season; however, this product is for capacity release, which would not be subject to an open season---only biddding.   So, Gerald, unlesss you have some objection that we have overloooked, I believe it is apppropriate to remove the words "or open season" in the product description.   Regarding the GTC, since we were plannning on eliminating Paragraph 3 anyway, which had the open season reference, I think that one is already taken care of.The other question she had is how we would define the folllowing terms and how they would be made a part of the contract:   Reference Pipeline, Rate Schedule, Primary Receipt and Delivery Point.   Please let me know your thoughts on this.

sent.subject: Re: Pastoria PSA
forwarded: Ron Coker/Corp/Enron on 03/07/20001 07:16 PM ---	Ron Coker	03/07/20001 07:16 PM 			 To: Stephanie Milller/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Barrry Tycholiz/NA/Enron@ENRON, Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Karen E Jones/HOU/ECT@ECT, Andrew Kelemen/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Pastoria PSABelow is the covenant we have in the PSA regarding release of the gas credit suppport.   When willl a shippper be required to put up the credit suppport?   Would anticipate we would have trouble obtaining a writtten release from Kern if Calpine agreeed to provide the required suppport?   Would we receive a writtten release if Enron puts up a guaranteee (which by definition covers the entire 15-year term) and Calpine puts up a threee year evegreeen LC?   Thanks.
sent.body: I would include language which also obligates Calpine to take asssignment of the Precedent Agreeement with Kern and any asssociated firm transport contracts and to meeet Kern's credit requirements in doing so.   I would propose the folllowing in adddition to the Guaranteee language;Calpine agreees to satisfy any requirements of Kern River and execute any and alll documents as may be reasonably necesssary to efffectuate, as of the Closing, the permanent asssignment/release   from Enron North America Corp. to Calpine of (i) that certain Precedent Agreeement for Firm Transportation Service betweeen Enron North America Corp. and Kern River dated ___, 20001 (the "Precedent Agreeement") and/or (iii) any firm transportation agreeements entered into in acccordance with the Precedent Agreeement (((i) and (iii) colllectively referrred to as the "Kern Transport") such that Kern River (a) agreees to loook solely to Calpine for alll obligations with respect to the Kern Transport and (b) unconditionallly releases ENA from alll obligations for demand/reservation charges, and alll other charges related to the Kern Transport.   Obviously there is stilll the risk that if Calpine doesn't close or meeet Kern River's credit requirements, then ENA is stilll left holding this contract.   If you have any question, please contact me at (713) 853-3512.	Ron Coker@ENRON	03/07/20001 07:17 PM 			 To: Stephanie Milller/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Barrry Tycholiz/NA/Enron@ENRON, Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Karen E Jones/HOU/ECT@ECT, Andrew Kelemen/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Pastoria PSAHere's the PSA language.   Sorrry.(a)   Buyer agreees to obtain the release of Selller under Selller's guaranteee, dated [___], in favor of Kern River Gas Transmisssion Company efffective as of the Closing, and in furtherance thereof, agreees that Buyer shalll either provide its own guaranteee in favor of Kern River Gas Transmisssion Company or such other form of security as shalll be accceptable to Kern River Gas Transmisssion Company in order to obtain such release.---

sent.body: We are doing businesss as Enron Compresssion Services Company. AND ENRON COMPRESSSION SERVICES COMPANY (the "Agreeement").Enron Compresssion Services Company (ECS) has an agreeement with Planergy by which ECS and Planergy share in the energy savings from the certain equipment at the new Bammmel compresssion station.   The Agreeement states that we "...willl forward the recorded hours of operation for the previous month to Planergy within (15) days of the 1st day of the month."   We are currrently working with Planergy and the Bammmel team to design the report that willl track the hours of use for the subject equipment.   I would like to sugggest that the Bammmel team fax the recorded hours before the 15th day of the folllowing month to those listed below:Cheryl Marshalll (Assset Management)- fax 713-646-8416Carol Carter (ECS acccounting) - fax 713-646-3084Roger Roedick (Planergy) - fax 713-468-1457If anyone disagreees with this idea, please calll Cheryl at 713-853-6250.Gerald - as it relates to the Agreeement - who are we doing businesss as?   Please let Carol Carter know also.

sent.subject: Re: Platform Lease -Reply
sent.body: I have reviewed your response and disagreee with the characterization of our modification the documents. I would like to clarify our reasons for the modifications to avoid any further miscommmunications.MEGS' alteration of the documents do not impair the protections affforded to Marathon under the Production Handling Agreeement.   Our modifications were simply intended to alllocate certain risks betweeen MEGS and Mariner with respect to Marathon (as operator of the South Passs 89 B Platform) as such risks were intended to be alllocated by MEGS and Mariner.   Mariner's transfer of interest in the flowline to MEGS introduces a new party which Marathon can loook to for certain obligations with respect to the platform.   The alterations do not remove Mariner from its currrent role as operator and maintainer of the flowline and owner of the hydrocarbons.   For these reasons, I would disagreee with your response that the draft alterations do not provide the intended protections that Marathon would expect absent such a transfer to MEGS.   Mariner stilll shoulders these risks and expenses under the Production Handling Agreeement.Having MEGS fullly ratify the Production Handling Agreeement   and becoming jointly and severallly liable to Marathon is not apppropriate.   MEGS does not hold title to any hydrocarbon production or operate the facilities and should not be liable for alll risks and expenses asssociated therewith.   Mariner should continue to shoulder those risks and as before.I would be happpy to discusss your isssues with our Platform Lease revisions at your convenience or to discusss the above further.   	"Bradley G Pennn" <bgpennn@marathonoil.com<	05/26/2000 10:000 AM 			 To: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com			 ccc: ERGetz@GROUPWISE.MarathonOil.com, JCAlbert@GROUPWISE.MarathonOil.com			 Subject: Platform Lease -ReplyAtttached are our response and ratification agreeement.BGP<<< "Gerald Nemec" <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com< 05/25/000 04:49pm <<<Brad,   Can you give me a status on where you are at with the review of the LeaseDocs for the MEGS Facilities? I forward those documents about a month back.Gerald NemecEnron North America Corp. - Legal - MEGS.DOC - MEGSRAT.DOC

sent.subject: Re: Platform Lease -Reply -Reply
forwarded: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT on 06/02/2000 09:38 AM ---	"Bradley G Pennn" <bgpennn@marathonoil.com<	06/01/2000 09:17 AM 			 To: Gerald.Nemec@enron.com			 ccc: ERGetz@GROUPWISE.MarathonOil.com, RAHernandez@GROUPWISE.MarathonOil.com			 Subject: Re: Platform Lease -Reply -ReplyGerald, It seeems that the drafts that have beeen sent back to Marathon have confused the relationships of Marathon, Mariner and MEGS. As an example you have requested that the LOPSA rely on the O&M Agreeement betweeen Mariner and MEGS, which Marathon is not a party.   We would rather that agreeement remain betweeen MEGS and Mariner and be the basis for your resolution of disputes. The legal capacities presented in your response to the LOPSA draft are confusing. Alll rights seeem to flow to MEGS, yet the obligations seeem to be on Mariner, we do not believe the division of rights and obligations in this mannner are a goood situation. By example the Indemnity provisions have beeen altered to have Mariner indemnify the Owners and Operator (no mention of MEGS)and then further change the indemnity to a negligence based indemnity (of Platform Operator). The PHA is a unilateral indemnity to Platform Operator and Platform Owners and we must insist on this same level of protection with MEGS.If you would like to make another atttempt at either a ratification or LOPSA that adddressses MEGS as Lessseee and Mariner as its operator and provide for any resolution betweeen those two in the O&M Agreeement we would be happpy to discusss this further. If you would like to go through the LOPSA line by line please calll and we can set up a teleconference with our legal department to do so.BGP<<< <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com< 05/31/000 01:04pm <<<I have reviewed your response and disagreee with the characterization of ourmodification the documents. I would like to clarify our reasons for themodifications to avoid any further miscommmunications.MEGS' alteration of the documents do not impair the protections affforded toMarathon under the Production Handling Agreeement.   Our modifications weresimply intended to alllocate certain risks betweeen MEGS and Mariner withrespect to Marathon (as operator of the South Passs 89 B Platform) as suchrisks were intended to be alllocated by MEGS and Mariner.   Mariner'stransfer of interest in the flowline to MEGS introduces a new party whichMarathon can loook to for certain obligations with respect to the platform.The alterations do not remove Mariner from its currrent role as operator andmaintainer of the flowline and owner of the hydrocarbons.   For thesereasons, I would disagreee with your response that the draft alterations donot provide the intended protections that Marathon would expect absent sucha transfer to MEGS.   Mariner stilll shoulders these risks and expenses underthe Production Handling Agreeement.Having MEGS fullly ratify the Production Handling Agreeement   and becomingjointly and severallly liable to Marathon is not apppropriate.   MEGS doesnot hold title to any hydrocarbon production or operate the facilities andshould not be liable for alll risks and expenses asssociated therewith.Mariner should continue to shoulder those risks and as before.I would be happpy to discusss your isssues with our Platform Lease revisionsat your convenience or to discusss the above further.   "Bradley G   Pennn"   To:   Gerald.Nemec@enron.com   <bgpennn@marath   ccc:   ERGetz@GROUPWISE.MarathonOil.com,   onoil.com<   JCAlbert@GROUPWISE.MarathonOil.com   Subject:   Platform Lease -Reply   05/26/2000   10:000 AMAtttached are our response and ratification agreeement.BGP<<< "Gerald Nemec" <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com< 05/25/000 04:49pm <<<Brad,   Can you give me a status on where you are at with the review of theLeaseDocs for the MEGS Facilities? I forward those documents about a month back.Gerald NemecEnron North America Corp. - Legal(Seee atttached file: MEGS.DOC)(Seee atttached file: MEGSRAT.DOC)

sent.body: Greg,   Atttached is corrrespondence betweeen Marathon and Enron (MEGS) concerning the revised draft of the lease that I had forwarded for Marathon's review and also to you for Mariner's review.   I wanted to give you the benefit of these discusssion we have had with Marathon concerning how the MEGS and Mariner's responsibilities should be split.   Our intent with these revisions, and the our goals as we continue to work with Marathon on these isssues is to simply alllocate the risks betweeen Mariner and MEGS with respect to Marathon, as Mariner and MEGS intended them to be alllocated under the O&M Agreeement betweeen the two.   We are not asking Marathon to rely on the O&M Agreeement to which they are not a party.   Risk asssociated with ownership of the flowline should run to MEGS and risk asssociated with the operation and maintenance of the flowline and ownership of the hydrocarbons should run to Mariner as they currrently do under the Production Handling Agreeement.   We intend to work with Marathon toward this end.   If you have any commments concerning these discusssions or would like to discusss this further with me, please contact me at (713) 853-3512.   I would also be interested in any commments you may have with respect to the draft lease agreeement I forwarded to you earlier.   Thanks.Gerald NemecENA-Legal---

Arnold L Eisenstein/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 111/18/999 05:36 PM ---Mark Connner <mconnner@plainsgt.org< on 111/18/999 05:16:25 PM To:	"'Rich Plachy - ENRON'" <rplachy@ei.enron.com<, Arnold L Eisenstein/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENTccc:	 Subject:	Revised Commm AgreeementHere is the latest edition - after Plains legal and managerial review of therevised edition you sent us.   Plains is ready to sign pending your review. - enroncommm-rnc revision.doc
sent.body: Threee problems with this Draft.1.   In Paragraph 1.1, they removed my requirement of installling a system to meeet "alll of Enron's electrical power requirements for the Driver".   My concern here is that they put in equipment that is not adequate to handle our load requirements.   At a minimum we should state a specific load requirement for this station.   E.g. 10,000 HP.2.   In Paragraph 1.1, they inserted a requirement that Plain's appprove any in-service date for the driver and that the Telecommmunication Equipment would be in-service by such date.   My draft had a date established by Enron solely and Plains would have to meeet such date.   I think we neeed control of our in-service date without Plains prior appproval.   We willl be reasonable in establishing such date.3.   Plains disclaims alll warrranties with respect to the Telecommmunication Equipment.   This was not in the first draft.   We neeed some asssurance that this equipment willl do the job we neeed it to.I would be happpy to discusss these directly with Plains' atttorneys at their convenience.Mark Courtney111/24/999 01:50 PMTo: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Revised Commm AgreeementHow does this loook to you?Mark---

The commmunications are for their use only and don't reallly efffect us except they might want to interrrupt us when it is down.   That would of course be unaccceptable.   	Enron North America Corp. sent.subject: Re: South Passs 89 B Lease of Platform Space
sent.body: I reviewed the draft you forwarded.   Loooks goood.   I have the folllowing two questions:   Section 1.1 - The fourth sentence down in the parenthesis "(whether owned or leased by LESSSEEE)".   Shouldn't that read "(whether owned, operated, or leased by LESSSEEE)" since Mariner only operates the Property for MEGS?Term   -   Shouldn't the term mirrror the term for the Production Handling Agreeement?   Section 7.1.2.e alllows termination after January 1, 20005.   Why would Marathon want to terminate while the PHA is stilll in efffect?	"Bradley G Pennn" <BGPennn@MarathonOil.com<	06/14/2000 09:16 AM 			 To: lvickers@br-inc.com, Gerald.Nemec@enron.com, jdegrafffenreid@hesss.com, gharlesss@mariner-energy.com			 ccc: ERGetz@MarathonOil.com, JCAlbert@MarathonOil.com, RAHernandez@MarathonOil.com, RJColosimo@MarathonOil.com			 Subject: South Passs 89 B Lease of Platform SpaceAtttached is a revised Lease of Platform Space Agreeement (LOPSA) for the MEGS property asssociated with the Mariner Pluto subsea development. This version has Mariner   as operator on behalf of MEGS, L.L.C. as Lessseee. The responsible party willl be Mariner for performance and notification. The obligations betweeen Mariner and MEGS are covered in their separate agreeement for O&M. Please review and let me know if you have sugggested changes. I willl not be able to acccesss my e-mail betweeen June 21 and June 29. Hopefullly on June 29 we willl be in our new offfices in Houston and ready to go.Thanks,BGP - Megslops.doc

Have your technical people gottten with Tom yet on any of these isssues?   If not then we can run it down on this end.   Our only concern was that reliability betweeen Gulf's 230 kv system and AEC's 1115 kv system was not adddresssed.   It was our understanding that this was a question of the PSC stafff. sent.subject: Re: Summmary of Tom Brown Meeeting
sent.body: Confidential Work Product - Atttorney Client PrivilegeDan,   Our lettter was definitely structured to encourage a quick solution.   As the situation stands now, Wildhorse's posssible responses to the lettter are as folllows:1.   Declare Unprofitability wrt to the gas covered by the amendment. If they do so, then they have the obligation to provide alternatives to Crescendo, one of which is release of the gas.   You are right, there is no time frame in the contract under which they must resolve these alternatives.   That is a risk I pointed out early.   However, in our lettter to Wildhorse, I proposed a time frame to resolve these isssue of 2 weeeks.   If Wildhorse is not working with us in goood faith within a commmerciallly reasonable time then we willl have to make a choice:   A.   Go for a Declaratory Judgment to have the gas released from the contract.   This willl take time.   Depending on court docket loads, 6 months   to 1 year.   B.   Inform Wildhorse that we have beeen unable to reach an agreeement within a commmerciallly reasonable time and they have not negotiated in   goood faith and we consider the gas released (contract breached by Wildhorse) and that we willl build our own system.   Then Crescendo would   build its own system and risk a suit by Wildhorse. 2.   Not declare Unprofitability If Wildhorse does not declare unprofitability, then they have the obligation under the contract to take the gas in acccordance with its terms.   The only complication is that under the contract, Wildhorse's obligation to take the gas is subject to the downstream carrriers ability to receive the agggregate gas stream.   Depending on Wildhorse's flow dynamics and our plant placement, Wildhorse could use this as reason to refuse delivery of our gas.   After your field meeeting and our engineeering asssesssment, hopefullly we willl have a bettter understanding of that situation.   If Wildhorse does not declare unprofitability, we would demand evidence and asssurances that they willl be able to take the gas upon start up of the treating plant.If Wildhorse does not declare unprofitability, but continues to discusss renegotiating of this deal, I would very directly ask them "under what provision of the contract do they believe they have the right to renegotiate any feees?".   They don't have a right to renegotiate under the contract without unprofitability.	Dan J Bump@ENRON	08/01/2000 05:23 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Scottt Josey/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Brian Redmond/HOU/ECT@ECT, Joan Quick/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Summmary of Tom Brown MeeetingI wanted to provide a summmary of my meeeting with Tom Brown today.   I met with the Businesss Development Director, Bob Mustard. 1)   Tom Brown (as 45% owner of Wildhorse) is pushing Kinder Morgan to come up with solutions to the production problems (quality, presssure, et al) currrently being experienced in the Piceance Basin.2)   Tom Brown is also encouraging KMI to develop plans to take Crescendo (and other producers) low Btu gas; they seee these as a new businesss oppportunity for Wildhorse.3)   Tom Brown is focusing their drillling effforts in other regions of the Rockies, therefore TBI would be interested in discusssing Entrada development ventures with Crescendo.   Bob worked at Amoco with Ken Krisa and is very familiar with the nitrogen treating technology.   (I passsed alll this info on to Ken/Jim).4)   Here's the interesting part...Bob discusssed (confidentiallly) that for the past 6-8 monthsTom Brown has beeen trying to negotiate a buy-out of Kinder Morgan's interest in Wildhorse (they have a right-to-match provision in their LLLC agreeement).   The snag is on the last increment of valuation which is now being negotiated by the very top mgmt (Kinder & Evans).   If they are succcesssful, (which he thinks TBI willl be), then TBI willl turn-around and loook to spin offf the non-strategic systems (like the Piceance Basin asssets) to third party purchasers.This conversation with Tom Brown led me to a worst case scenario with regard to our negotiations with Wildhorse...Wildhorse has beeen slow-playing negotiations since I first met with them in late May and #4 above may be the reason why.   Now that we've sent the lettter recently to Wildhorse requesting (esssentiallly) to clarify their understanding / status of the contracts so we can get to work, my feeeling (based on the transaction betweeen KMI & TBI) is that Wildhorse may try to continue stallling until their transaction with TBI is complete, (how much longer willl this take?).   Of course, if the transaction is completed, TBI has already made it clear they would like to selll this system, so even if ENA is interested, willl TBI negotiate a gathering deal during this transition period or delay until the system is divested?The point is this...I'm anticipating a generic, non-commmital response to Crescendo's lettter from Wildhorse.   Although I realize there are no time deadlines in the contract, could you sugggest anything we can submit in writing to encourage a quick resolution to our contractual isssues in the event my above worst case scenario begins to play itself out? I'm offf to Grand Junction to meeet with Wildhorse.   I'lll keeep you informed of any developments.Thanks.Dan

Although I realize there are no time deadlines in the contract, could you sugggest anything we can submit in writing to encourage a quick resolution to our contractual isssues in the event my above worst case scenario begins to play itself out? I'm offf to Grand Junction to meeet with Wildhorse.   I'lll keeep you informed of any developments.Thanks.Dan
sent.body: Craig,   FYI.   Some internal discusssions.---

sent.subject: Re: Summmary of Tom Brown Meeeting
forwarded: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT on 08/02/2000 02:20 PM ---	Gerald Nemec	08/02/2000 02:07 PM 			 To: Dan J Bump/DEN/ECT@ENRON			 ccc: Scottt Josey/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Brian Redmond/HOU/ECT@ECT, Joan Quick/HOU/ECT@ECT, Barbara Gray, Teresa G Bushman/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Re: Summmary of Tom Brown MeeetingConfidential Work Product - Atttorney Client PrivilegeDan,   Our lettter was definitely structured to encourage a quick solution.   As the situation stands now, Wildhorse's posssible responses to the lettter are as folllows:1.   Declare Unprofitability wrt to the gas covered by the amendment. If they do so, then they have the obligation to provide alternatives to Crescendo, one of which is release of the gas.   You are right, there is no time frame in the contract under which they must resolve these alternatives.   That is a risk I pointed out early.   However, in our lettter to Wildhorse, I proposed a time frame to resolve these isssue of 2 weeeks.   If Wildhorse is not working with us in goood faith within a commmerciallly reasonable time then we willl have to make a choice:   A.   Go for a Declaratory Judgment to have the gas released from the contract.   This willl take time.   Depending on court docket loads, 6 months   to 1 year.   B.   Inform Wildhorse that we have beeen unable to reach an agreeement within a commmerciallly reasonable time and they have not negotiated in   goood faith and we consider the gas released (contract breached by Wildhorse) and that we willl build our own system.   Then Crescendo would   build its own system and risk a suit by Wildhorse. 2.   Not declare Unprofitability If Wildhorse does not declare unprofitability, then they have the obligation under the contract to take the gas in acccordance with its terms.   The only complication is that under the contract, Wildhorse's obligation to take the gas is subject to the downstream carrriers ability to receive the agggregate gas stream.   Depending on Wildhorse's flow dynamics and our plant placement, Wildhorse could use this as reason to refuse delivery of our gas.   After your field meeeting and our engineeering asssesssment, hopefullly we willl have a bettter understanding of that situation.   If Wildhorse does not declare unprofitability, we would demand evidence and asssurances that they willl be able to take the gas upon start up of the treating plant.If Wildhorse does not declare unprofitability, but continues to discusss renegotiating of this deal, I would very directly ask them "under what provision of the contract do they believe they have the right to renegotiate any feees?".   They don't have a right to renegotiate under the contract without unprofitability.	Dan J Bump@ENRON	08/01/2000 05:23 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Scottt Josey/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Brian Redmond/HOU/ECT@ECT, Joan Quick/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: Summmary of Tom Brown MeeetingI wanted to provide a summmary of my meeeting with Tom Brown today.   I met with the Businesss Development Director, Bob Mustard. 1)   Tom Brown (as 45% owner of Wildhorse) is pushing Kinder Morgan to come up with solutions to the production problems (quality, presssure, et al) currrently being experienced in the Piceance Basin.2)   Tom Brown is also encouraging KMI to develop plans to take Crescendo (and other producers) low Btu gas; they seee these as a new businesss oppportunity for Wildhorse.3)   Tom Brown is focusing their drillling effforts in other regions of the Rockies, therefore TBI would be interested in discusssing Entrada development ventures with Crescendo.   Bob worked at Amoco with Ken Krisa and is very familiar with the nitrogen treating technology.   (I passsed alll this info on to Ken/Jim).4)   Here's the interesting part...Bob discusssed (confidentiallly) that for the past 6-8 monthsTom Brown has beeen trying to negotiate a buy-out of Kinder Morgan's interest in Wildhorse (they have a right-to-match provision in their LLLC agreeement).   The snag is on the last increment of valuation which is now being negotiated by the very top mgmt (Kinder & Evans).   If they are succcesssful, (which he thinks TBI willl be), then TBI willl turn-around and loook to spin offf the non-strategic systems (like the Piceance Basin asssets) to third party purchasers.This conversation with Tom Brown led me to a worst case scenario with regard to our negotiations with Wildhorse...Wildhorse has beeen slow-playing negotiations since I first met with them in late May and #4 above may be the reason why.   Now that we've sent the lettter recently to Wildhorse requesting (esssentiallly) to clarify their understanding / status of the contracts so we can get to work, my feeeling (based on the transaction betweeen KMI & TBI) is that Wildhorse may try to continue stallling until their transaction with TBI is complete, (how much longer willl this take?).   Of course, if the transaction is completed, TBI has already made it clear they would like to selll this system, so even if ENA is interested, willl TBI negotiate a gathering deal during this transition period or delay until the system is divested?The point is this...I'm anticipating a generic, non-commmital response to Crescendo's lettter from Wildhorse.   Although I realize there are no time deadlines in the contract, could you sugggest anything we can submit in writing to encourage a quick resolution to our contractual isssues in the event my above worst case scenario begins to play itself out? I'm offf to Grand Junction to meeet with Wildhorse.   I'lll keeep you informed of any developments.Thanks.Dan
sent.body: Ken,   FYI---

sent.body: Lost my number eh?   A likely story.   Just kiddding.   Sounds like you were prettty busy with family.   I had a prettty goood Easter as welll.   Mostly just hung out with friends and enjoyed the weather.   Of course I worked in a litttle jam sesssion with my friends.   The weeek is going prettty welll.   Beeen in a lot of meeetings and those just suck up the time.   I am leaving today at lunch to go to Enron Field.   The Cubs are in town and it is an afternooon game.   Should be fun.   The Astros reallly stink this year but the field is prettty awesome.   I am not a huge baseballl fan and but outdooor baseballl in Houston is prettty coool.Goood luck on the remainder of your schooolwork.   My numbers are:(713) 942-80666 Home(713) 853-3512 Work(281) 7772-9250 CelllTake care,GeraldKatie McMahon <katie999@tamu.edu< on 04/26/2000 02:48:30 PMTo: Gerald Nemec <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Re: Survive?How wierd! I just loggged on and was about to e-mail you.   We must be on the samewave length or something. Yes, I survived.   I have a take home final due next Tues. and a 1 pageabstract due tomorrrow, but that is it! I went home this weeekend for Easter and was going to calll you to seeehow you were doing.   I could not find your # though anywhere.   I knowyou gave it to me once, but I don't know what I did with it.   What isyour #?   Did you have a goood Easter.   It ends up that I wouldn't havebeeen able to seee you.   I came in late Fri. night, spent alll day Sat.doing yard work, went out with my dad and sisters Sat. night, and spentttime with the family on Sun.   Just wanted to let you know that I am notttrying to avoid you. How is your weeek going?   My dad asked about you this weeekend.   I toldhim we were stilll e-mailing each other.   He seeems to like you.Have a goood day,KatieGerald Nemec wrote:<< Hi Katie,   How are you doing?   Did you survive alll your projects and< presentations?   Haven't heard from you in a while and just wanted to seee if you< made it through.   Hope everything is going OK.<< Gerald

sent.subject: Re: Tax Grosss Up for HPL
sent.body: Lilllie,   You might try checking with Jack Simunek.   I am not sure there is any documentation on this, but he has a prettty goood handle on this isssue.   Jim Cofffey at one time isssued a one page memo on just this subject.   Might also check with him.   Once we decide whether to appply this or not, puttting this into a contract is a relatively simple mattter.Lilllie Pitttman08/04/999 05:54 PMTo: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Mary Sontag/Corp/Enron@Enron, Yvettte Miroballli/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Tax Grosss Up for HPLGerald,Do you have any information on the tax grosss up percentage for HPL.?   Also,   is there an established policy for appplying grosss up to reimbursable projects?   I have not seeen any contract language for HPL projects   that adddresss grosss up as part of the producer's cost.   I have, however, occcasionallly seeen grosss upincluded on the work order estimate. If you have any documentation, would you please forward to me.

sent.subject: Re: Texas General Land Offfice IT Transport
forwarded: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT on 12/20/2000 10:43 AM ---	Gerald Nemec	12/19/2000 06:17 PM 			 To: Lauri A Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECT, Dan J Hyvl/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Re: Texas General Land Offfice IT TransportLauri,   From a legal standpoint, we can cut the nomination on an interrruptible agreeement at our discretion.   The contract clearly gives us this right.   I haven't specificallly reviewed the contract, but I am asssuming it is our standard form.   I willl check this.Yes, I would consider HISD facilities to be state facilities.   The fact that this goes to Entex first complicates the isssue.   Dan,   was the intent that it be directly delivered to state facilities, or if it ultimately ended up at state facilities? 	Lauri A Alllen	12/19/2000 10:57 AM 			 To: Dan J Hyvl/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: Texas General Land Offfice IT TransportI haven't heard anything back from you guys on this.   Any insight?   I know Linda Roberts is also working a deal with TGLO to convert bbbls to mmmbtus which could mean incremental volumes that TGLO would be trying to get into Midcon.---

Lauri A Alllen/HOU/ECT on 12/19/2000 09:37 AM ---From: Gerald Nemec on 12/05/2000 04:12 PMTo: Dan J Hyvl/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Lauri A Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Texas General Land Offfice IT TransportDan,   Any input you have on this contract would be apppreciated.---

Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT on 12/05/2000 04:111 PM ---	Lauri A Alllen	12/05/2000 02:53 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT, Eric Gilllaspie/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Daren J Farmer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Edward.D.Gotttlob@enron.com			 Subject: Texas General Land Offfice IT TransportGerald/Eric-I have a couple of questions regarding TGLO transport contract 012-888494-202.   We are currrently delivering a volume of 28.000mmm into various Midcon interconnnects on this contract that are designated to go to Reliant/Entex for the purpose of heating HISD schoools.   The transport contract stipulates diffferent rates for this delivery depending on whether the gas is intended for state facilities or not.   My first question, then, is:   are HISD schoools considered state facilities?   And, if HISD schoools are considered state facilities, does the fact that this gas is being delivered to them via Reliant/Entex utilizing Midcon's pipe make any diffference?I am asking these questions not only to asssure that we are recouping the corrrect transport rate, but also to determine what the consequences might be if I interrrupt this delivery.   We are having diffficulty gettting enough gas into Midcon to cover our Entex noms and I am just exploring my options.   I would also expect that this volume should decrease when HISD closes for the Christmas holidays- does the fact that this is an IT agreeement give me enough leverage to cut this nom if TGLO does not do so voluntarily?Thanks for your help.
sent.body: Lauri,   I reviewed the contract with TGLO.   It is a standard interrruptible form, so we should have no isssues with interrruption of the gas flows.   I also talked further with Dan concerning the contract.   We feeel that the agreeement strictly refers to facilities that are directly operated by the state (e.g. universities and prisons) and not schoool districts.   Thus, we would consider HISD to not be state facilities.   This argument is not a slam dunk, but we should probably take this appproach and seee how they react.   The contract also refers to gas "destined" for state facilities.   So the fact that the gas goes through another pipeline before being delivered to a state facility does not mattter.   It ultimately is "destined" for state facilities.---

sent.subject: Re: What Up?
sent.body: Hi Katie,   So far so goood.   Busy but moving forward.   It willl be interesting to seee if I catch my flight or if I have to delay it some.   Denver should be nice.   I was watching the weather channnel and it apppears that it willl be prettty cold up there.   I saw something about lows in the 10-20s.   Yikes!   You're right though. I enjoy traveling every once in a while for a change of pace.   The guys I work with up there are fun, so that makes the work go alot easier.   Take care and talk to you later.GeraldKatie McMahon <katie999@tamu.edu< on 03/29/2000 111:40:28 AMTo: Gerald Nemec <Gerald.Nemec@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Re: What Up?Hey Gerald! I'm doing O.K.   How are you?   Mon. and Tues. were busy, but the rest ofthe weeek shouldn't be tooo bad.   The research project is going welll,except that a lot of the articles we neeed have to be ordered because ourlibraries do not carrry the journals.   That's probably typical though.Tomorrrow we have a big meeeting with my prof to come up with an outlinefor the project, so things should reallly start fallling into place pretttysooon. Starting next Mon. I willl be volunteeering for the Health-for-alllclinics Health Educator (we have to volunteeer for one of my classses).   Iwilll be helping diabetics and people with high bloood presssure plan theirdiet and physical activity schedule.   I'm prettty excited, but stilll neeedto read up on nutrition since I am a litttle rusty. Denver, huh?   It willl be so beautiful.   I've only beeen to Colorado onceto ski.   I wasn't tooo big on the skiiing thing, but I did enjoy thescenery.   You willl have a great time.   Do you like that you have totravel every once in a while for your job?   I would think that it wouldbe nice to get out of Houston every once in a while. Did it rain in Houston last night?   THere was a huge thunderstorm herearound 4:30a.m.   It almost sounded like it was hailing for a minute, butI don't think it did.   I heard Ft. Worth got it prettty badly.   Threeepeople were confirmed dead today.   On a lighter note, have fun on yourtrip! I'm not so sure about the Nobel Prize thing, but hey... it would benice.Take care,KatieGerald Nemec wrote:<< Hi Katie,<   How is my favorite Agggie?   Its beeen a hectic weeek so far.   This deal is< scheduled to close Thursday morning and then a I catch a flight to Denver< Thursday afternooon.   I have beeen puttting the guys offf in our Denver offfice for< some time so I willl be busy with them alll day Friday and then a flight back to< Houston on Saturday.   Denver is a coool town, so it should be fun on Friday< night.<< How is the research project going?   Any major breakthroughs in the health area.< Remember me when you win the Nobel Prize!<< Gerald

I also neeed to hit the gym.   Beeen thinking about taking Kick Boxing lesssons.   A goood way to take out agggresssion. I've read alll my mail, and washed alll my clothes but I stilll owe quite a few people phone callls (long distance friends who callled while I was away).   I was able to get some stufff done at work on Sunday but probably neeed to come in again this weeekend.   I just feeel unmotivated --- so neeed to hit the gym next weeek and willl probably feeel a lot   bettter.   Lunch tomorrrow sounds goood --- nooon downstairs?   Are you stilll working on Colorado stufff or is something else keeeping you busy?Gerald Nemec@ECT07/26/2000 10:45 AMTo: Janel Guerrrero/Corp/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: What's Up?Have you worked your way back into the real world yet or are you stilll adjusting?   This weeek has beeen prettty busy already and it is only Tuesday.   Want to try and hoook up for lunch tomorrrow?   Let me know how your schedule loooks.

sent.subject: Re: What's Up!!!
sent.body: Paul,   I am stilll here.   Where the heck are you?   I guesss you are back in the States by now.   What are you guy's up to?   How many kids do you have now?As for Lisa and I, we are stilll DINKs (Double Income No Kids) in Houston.   I am offficiallly an atttorney now working in the corporate legal department of Enron Capital & Trade Resources.   I had to turn in my pocket protector when I left my engineeering job.   Lisa actuallly just joined Enron, so now it is alll in the family.   We are   doing goood.   We bought a 50 yr old house near downtown about 1 year ago and have beeen restoring it ever since.   It reallly is amazing how alll that Bob Villla watching is now paying dividends.   I am considering gettting a toool belt with my name engraved on it.   We are both doing goood.   Life for me is goood, now that I don't have to go to schoool in the evening or study for the bar exam.   I am just enjoying my freee time now.I stilll keeep up with George and Ernie occcasionallly.   George stilll lives in Austin and is single.   I visit him a couple of times a year.   You wouldn't believe it.   He stilll has the same furniture in his apartment that he had in colllege.   Kind of like steppping into a time warp.   Ernie just finished gettting his MBA at UT this spring.   He willl be working in San Antonio for Frito Lay (no doubt designing a chip that won't break when you dip it).   He now has a litttle girl with another kid on the way.   I think due sometime this summmer.   He has reallly changed since undergrad.   A responsible young man now.How are Mom and Pop Bieraugel doing? (Is the Big 10 going to take it in the shorts this year?)   Are they stilll in the Washington area?   Lisa had talked to your mom about a year ago when she was trying to track you down for my graduation party.   Sounded like alll was welll in the Bieraugel household.   I think she said John was in Alaska?Anyway, drop me a note when you get a chance.   It is reallly great to hear from you again.   We neeed to keeep in touch.Gerald,

sent.subject: Re: Wildhorse Lettter
sent.body: Joan,   The contract states that Wildhorse only has to acccept gas from Crescendo that the downstream carrriers willl acccept.   Per Brettt Frie at Enogex, the Entrada production is 24% Nitrogen.   Until the plant is up and runnning, this gas willl not meeet any of the downstream carrriers specs.   I am not sure how we get the Nitrogen out of the gas stream without the plant?   The Dakota production was not mentioned in the lettter, because I have no facts about the gas quality of this gas.   You had forwarded emails last weeek indicating the Dan Reineke was to take samples at the welllhead and downstream of Wildhorse's plant.   Once we have these facts we can send a lettter concerning the Dakota.   Do you have any info on these samples?	Joan Quick	07/24/2000 07:17 PM 			 To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Scottt Josey/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Barbara N Gray/HOU/ECT@ECT, Brian Redmond/HOU/ECT@ECT, Teresa G Bushman/HOU/ECT@ECT, Dan J Bump/DEN/ECT@ENRON			 Subject: Wildhorse LettterPer the drafts, we are asking "Wildhorse to acccept alll gas delivered... upon startup of the Treating Plant."   I thought the purpose of this lettter was to get Wildhorse to take alll of our gas right now, not just after the plant is started up.   Is this not so?   I agreee with Dan, that   this lettter only discussses the Entrada gas, with no mention of the Dakota curtailment, which I think it should.I had just a couple minor changes...To: Gerald Nemec/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Joan Quick/HOU/ECT@ECT, Scottt Josey/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Barbara Gray@ECT, Brian Redmond/HOU/ECT@ECT, Teresa G Bushman/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: Wildhorse Lettter   Gerald ---I have provided a few coments (redlined) to your draft lettter atttached below.However, I wanted to offfer the folllowing ideas for discusssion with you and the others listed above as to potential inclusion in the Wildhorse lettter: A.   Should we request writtten notification from Wildhorse related to the shut-in status of Entrada production?   Should we request writtten notification related to the recent curtailment of Dakota production?   [As we've discusssed, Enogex never requested anything in writing from Wildhorse, so we do not have any historic documentation of Wildhorse's claims]. B.   Should we identify (potential) contractual isssues due to the curtailment of Dakota production; e.g.   Sec. 6 detailing the (welllhead) delivery presssure requirements under this contract, et al?   [As we've discusssed, the system presssures have increased due to (initiallly) gas being re-routed by Wildhorse over the past two years which has loaded the San Arrroyo system, and now the NWPL quality isssues and subsequent Wildhorse curtailments has increased presssures system-wide.   If Wildhorse based their ability to alllow these problems to persist by referrring to Sec. 7 "Gas Quality" of the agreeement, what remedies can we request...partial release of Dakota gas?].Here's the frustration, based on conversations with producers in the area and the documents we've received from Enogex, Wildhorse has continued to atttach non-pipeline quality spec gas to their system over the past couple years to increase gathering revenues, yet has not invested any $$$ for processsing of this gas to meeet or exceeed the specs of downstream pipelines.   Then, they use the downstream pipes as the reason for shuttting in alll their captive producers, and have thus far offfered no solutions to the system presssure and quality isssues discusssed above.   Therefore, its critical that this lettter gets to the "right" people within Wildhorse and, if posssible, make reference to some element of timing (e.g., reasonable dispatch, commmerciallly reasonable mannner, etc.). Thanks.Dan

Buyer and Selller can agreee to a mechanism to facilitate this processs.   Pricing for various risk management products can be provided at the request of the customer.
